entry.title: Re: When I called BAPI_SALESORDER_CHANGE, "Update was canceled" received from author &quo
entry.content: The error message in transaction SM13 directed me to check transaction ST22, and the corresponding ST22 dump is as follows.

entry.title: Re: When I called BAPI_SALESORDER_CHANGE, "Update was canceled" received from author &quo
entry.content: An exception has occurred in class "CX_SY_OPEN_SQL_DB". This exception wa caught in procedure "SD_PARTNER_UPDATE" "(FUNCTION)" or propagated by a RAISING clause. Since the caller of the procedure could not have anticipated this exception, the current program was terminated. The reason for the exception occurring was: The reason for the exception is: When an Open SQL array insert is performed, trying to insert a record into the database table "VBPA" causes the function to terminate if a record with the same key already exists. (When an Open SQL individual record insert is performed, this situation does not cause the function to terminate. SY-SUBRC is set to 4 instead.)

entry.title: Re: When I called BAPI_SALESORDER_CHANGE, "Update was canceled" received from author &quo
entry.content: How should I modify the code based on the following message? If the exception cannot be prevented, "CX_SY_OPEN_SQL_DB" must be caught withi procedure "SD_PARTNER_UPDATE" "(FUNCTION)" or declared in the procedure's RAISING clause. To prevent the exception, note the following: Open SQL array insert should only be used if it is certain that none of the records specified already exists on the database. If this cannot be guaranteed, exception CX_SY_OPEN_SQL_DB should be intercepted, and the error must be resolved. If the error occurs in a non-modfied SAP program, you might be able to find a solution in the SAP Notes system. If you have access to the SAP Notes system, check there first using the following keywords: "DBSQL_DUPLICATE_KEY_ERROR" CX_SY_OPEN_SQL_DB "SAPLV05I" bzw. LV05IU15 "SD_PARTNER_UPDATE" If you cannot solve the problem yourself, please send the following information to SAP: 1. The description of the problem (short dump) Please press the "Local File‚Äù button in the current display. 2. The relevant system log To do this, call the system log in transaction SM21. Restrict the time interval to ten minutes before the short dump and five minutes after it. In the display, choose System -> List -> Save -> Local File (unconverted). 3. If these are programs of your own, or modified SAP programs: The source text of the programs To do this, please choose "Other Utilities -> Upload/Download -> Download". 4. Details regarding the conditions under which the error occurred or which actions and input caused the error. which actions and input caused the error.

entry.title: Issues with SAP Business Hub REST API consumption in CAP App
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I have a scenario, where I need to fetch all data from OMF Product API which is available in SAP Business Acclerator Hub as a REST service.

Overview | Products | SAP Business Accelerator Hub

When I import the JSON/YAML service as directed in all CAP guides, it is imported. But there is no entity definition.

My objective is to fetch all the records with $top and $skip and show it in a simple CAP List View app without storing it in persistence storage (Like HANA Cloud). 

Can you provide a guide or help on how I can achieve it? I have done it through the REST Proxy method but it is failing to get a large set of data and getting timeout.

DB Schema

entity Product {
  key id                          : UUID;
      displayId                   : String;
      externalSystemReferences    : String;
      name                        : String;
      productType                 : String;
      description                 : String;
      published                   : Boolean;
      replicationType             : String;
      soldElectronically          : Boolean;
      markedForDeletion           : Boolean;
      activeMarketIds             : String;
      aspectId                    : String;
      baseUnitOfMeasure           : String;
      physicalProductCategory     : String;
      physicalProductGroup        : String;
      physicalProductItemCategory : String;
      physicalProductType         : String;
      salesAreaData               : String;
      unitOfMeasures              : String;
}

 SERVICE.JS

const { default: cds } = require("@sap/cds");

module.exports = cds.service.impl(async function () {
    const {
        Product
    } = this.entities;
    var firstRead = true;
    this.before('READ', Product, async (req) => {
        try {
            if (firstRead) {
                var recfound = 0;
                var pageNumber = 0; 
                var pageSize = req.query.SELECT.limit.rows.val;
                do {
                    const sapOmf = await cds.connect.to('sapOmfProductApi');
                    const resp = await sapOmf.get('/product-management/v1/products?pageNumber=' + pageNumber); // + "&pageSize=" + pageSize);
                    const products = resp;
                    const entries = [];
                    //products.forEach(product => {
                    for (const product of products) {
                        const extSystem = product.externalSystemReferences;
                        let extSysText = '';
                        if (extSystem) {
                            extSystem.forEach(es => {
                                extSysText += es.externalId + '-' + es.externalSystemId + ",";
                            });
                        }

                        const prodDetail = await sapOmf.get('/product-management/v1/products/' + product.id);
                        const amkid = prodDetail.activeMarketIds;
                        const salesArea = prodDetail.aspectsData.physicalProduct.salesAreaData;
                        const uom = prodDetail.aspectsData.physicalProduct.unitOfMeasures;
                        let mktext = '';
                        if (amkid) {
                            amkid.forEach(mk => {
                                mktext += mk + '-';
                            });
                        }
                        let satext = '';
                        if (salesArea) {
                            salesArea.forEach(area => {
                                satext += 'Active:' + area.active + '-' + 'Distribution Channel:' + area.distributionChannel + '-' +
                                    'Division:' + area.division + '-' + 'Pricing Ref Product:' + area.pricingReferenceProduct + '-' +
                                    'Product Pricing Group:' + area.productPricingGroup + '-' + 'Sales Org:' + area.salesOrganization + ',';
                            });
                        }

                        let uomtext = '';
                        if (uom) {
                            uom.forEach(um => {
                                uomtext += um.alternativeUnitOfMeasure + '-' + um.numerator + '-' + um.denominator + ',';
                            });
                        }
                        entries.push({
                            id: product.id,
                            displayId: product.displayId,
                            externalSystemReferences: extSysText,
                            name: product.name,
                            productType: product.productType,
                            description: product.description,
                            published: product.published,
                            replicationType: product.replicationType,
                            soldElectronically: product.soldElectronically,
                            markedForDeletion: product.markedForDeletion,
                            activeMarketIds: mktext,
                            salesAreaData: satext,
                            unitOfMeasures: uomtext,
                            aspectId: prodDetail.aspectsData.physicalProduct.aspectId,
                            baseUnitOfMeasure: prodDetail.aspectsData.physicalProduct.baseUnitOfMeasure,
                            physicalProductType: prodDetail.aspectsData.physicalProduct.physicalProductType,
                            physicalProductItemCategory: prodDetail.aspectsData.physicalProduct.physicalProductItemCategory,
                            physicalProductCategory: prodDetail.aspectsData.physicalProduct.physicalProductCategory,
                            physicalProductGroup: prodDetail.aspectsData.physicalProduct.physicalProductGroup
                        });
                    }
                    // delete all countries

                    await cds.tx(req).run(INSERT.into(Product).entries(entries));
                    firstRead = false;
                    pageNumber++;
                    recfound = entries.length;

                } while (recfound > 0);
                return req;
            }
        } catch (err) {
            req.error(500, err.message);
        }
    });
});

This is using a schema and trying to insert data in that DB table every time. I am sure this not the best method and for large set of data it is not working. Please let me know the best way and how I can fetch data in bunch like 30 records at a time.

entry.title: Re: Period Control Depreciation and Risk of IFRS Compliance
entry.content:
Hi Divesh,

Customers should not be able to choose non-compliant methods and manners for the product to be IFRS Compliant. Also, when non-compliant methods exist, it would also be reasonable to assume that the backend processing (such as a Cartesian Product) may inflict some further non-compliance that is not visible to the customer and reporting the incorrect accounting numbers!

entry.title: Re: Understanding Relationship Types in SAP CAP: One-to-One, One-to-Many, and Many-to-Many
entry.content:
@Saone yes, you can actually do that

The difference here is that what you applied is known as managed associations. This means the CDS generates the foreign key and the on clause through the existing primary key.

The example provided was using an unmanaged association. Unmanaged associations explicitly specify arbitrary join conditions in their on clause, which refer to available foreign key fields.

For the sake of conciseness and comprehensibility, it is recommended to use managed associations for to-one associations.

entry.title: Re: BoE ‚Äì AP: Why Can‚Äôt We Set Maturity Date per Supplier...
entry.content:
Hi Divyesh, 

Thank you for your reply.

Yes, based on my previous testing, the BoE maturity date in the system is currently determined by the payment terms. May I confirm if this is standard system behavior and best practice?

Also, thank you for suggesting the approach of creating vendor-specific payment terms and assigning them in the supplier master. However, there is only one field available in the supplier master for maintaining payment terms, and we are currently using that to define the payment terms for supplier invoices, not for BoE.

If we assign a specific payment term in the supplier master, does that mean it will be applied to both the supplier invoice and the BoE maturity date? In our case, the payment terms for supplier invoices and BoE ‚Äì AP are different. 

For example:

  • Supplier Master: ABC | Payment Terms: Payable immediately, Due net, Baseline date at end of the month

  • If supplier invoice created for Supplier ABC,  then this will be due at the end of the month.

  • Before the invoice due date, the user would execute an automatic payment run and pay the invoice via BoE.

  • At that point, the BoE maturity date should ideally be determined automatically based on the contract term set per supplier (e.g. 60 days).

  • So, if I run the payment on 28 July 2025, the BoE maturity date should automatically be 26 September 2025 based on a 60-day maturity term.

Appreciate it if you could check the explanation above and share your feedbac

Thanks in advance!

Best regards, 

HY

entry.title: Re: Message dteermination for PO: Exclusive indicator not...
entry.content:
Yes you are right. The exclusive indicator in the access sequence applies within a single message type, not across multiple message types. So yes, because you‚Äôve defined ZMAI and ZPRI as separate message types, SAP evaluates the access sequence independently for each one, even if they share the same schema.

For ZPRI, SAP finds the vendor-specific condition record via the Doc.Type/Purch.Org/Vendor combination and stops there because of the exclusive flag. Then, for ZMAI, it runs the same access sequence independently and finds the general condition record for Doc.Type NB‚Äîeven though ZPRI already succeeded. The system doesn‚Äôt cross-check between message types. Each message type runs its own determination logic, and if both find valid condition records, both get triggered.

In order to overcome from this issue, have a single message type (e.g., ZPO) and differentiate output medium (email vs. print) via processing routines or partner functions. Alternatively, add a requirement routine to ZMAI that checks if ZPRI was already determined and suppresses ZMAI. Consider using output control via BRF+ (if you're on S/4HANA) for more flexible logic.

entry.title: Re: Changing LGORT for WM Staging (CO02/LB10)
entry.content: Look into Function Module LTAP_CREATE_TR or LTA_CREATE_TR, which is involved in TO creation. Use implicit enhancement at the beginning of the routine where LGORT is set. You can dynamically override LGORT based on your custom logic (e.g., material type, storage location, etc.). The other option is to explore with BADI_LE_WM_STAGING

entry.title: SAP IBP Inventory - EOQ Key Figures questions
entry.content:
Hi all,

I'm building an EOQ scenario calculation and trying to get a understanding of the KF's used in EOQ and Service Level Calculation. 

Unfortunately, the IBP Help page does not clearly explain the context or logic behind how these input key figures should be populated. I would really appreciate any guidance or feedback from those who have implemented or tested a similar setup.

The scenario is simple: an external supplier delivers goods to only one DC, which is also customer facing. Transport and customer ratios are 1. The Demand Forecast is 100,000 pcs per week. Supplier lead + transport time is 4 weeks with no frozen horizon maintained. I have activated time-varying costs per all three input KF's. 

KF1: Demand Rate Per Period
Should this be populated with the weekly product forecast (i.e., 100,000 pcs), or should it represent the 4-week forecast corresponding to the supplier lead+ transport time (400,000 pcs)?
The standard EOQ formula assumes an annual demand, but IBP Inventory Optimization works with a weekly planning period by default..

KF2: Holding Cost Rate Per Period
Does this refer to the warehousing/inventory carrying costs?
For example, if I expect to hold 100,000 pcs in a period, should this key figure reflect the total cost of storing those units for one week?

KF3: Transportation Fixed Cost Per Order
Should this include both transportation and goods receipt (GR) handling costs?
Also, how should we handle volume-based differentiation‚Äîe.g., receiving three containers costs more than one, but EOQ assumes a fixed cost per order. 

Thanks in advance for your support!

entry.title: Administration of SAP PAPM Cloud using BYOD Standalone SAP HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,

In my previous blog post, SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud Subscription with BYOD plan, I have shared to you how to subscribe with the newly release plan of SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud(SAP PAPM Cloud) which is the Bring Your Own Database(BYOD) plan.

With this new plan, you can maximize the SAP PAPM Cloud solution to perform high-volume data calculations and processing with more efficiency from your existing Standalone SAP HANA Cloud Database(Standalone HCDB) and SAP Datasphere.

What do we mean by efficiency? Imagine, your high-volume data is already sitting on your existing Standalone HCDB or SAP Datasphere where your SAP PAPM Cloud is mapped or connected. Therefore, creation of connections like Remote Source is not needed as you only need to perform the proper granting of privileges to technical schemas of your SAP PAPM Cloud.

Sounds cool right? Before we proceed on how you can perform integration such as the scenario above, it is important for you to know first that the Default and BYOD plan are still functionally the same. Absolutely no difference and still uses one code line.

The only difference is just the plan itself.

Alright, I hope that‚Äôs clear for us. Let‚Äôs now proceed with what‚Äôs happening when we subscribed to a BYOD plan of SAP PAPM Cloud.

Note: This blog post focuses on the usage of Standalone HCDB as the database in BYOD plan of SAP PAPM Cloud. Please stay tuned for the next blog post focusing on SAP Datasphere as the database in BYOD Plan.

Important topics are divided into 3 chapters so you can focus on what is relevant for your use case.

  1. Introducing technical users in Standalone HCDB.
  2. Authorization Grants for Standard Model
  3. Authorization Grants for Universal Model

Introducing technical users in Standalone HCDB BYOD plan

Since you can use multiple SAP PAPM Cloud tenants on one Standalone HCDB it is necessary for you to know what are the available schemas you can use to perform such integration in your own database.

SAP_PAPM_ADMIN like user

Once you subscribed to  SAP PAPM Cloud that uses BYOD plan, a user will be generated in Administration > Settings that you can use to login on your Standalone HCDB.

SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_<TENANTID>_<UNIQUEID>_RT.

Please take note of this IDs as it will be the indicator who owns the artifact on the Database level in case you have multiple tenants connected to your Standalone HCDB.

Please take note that the Database user above does not equate to the roles granted to SAP_PAPM_ADMIN from default subscription. In BYOD, you have the freedom to grant the roles which you think are needed for your users.

If you wish to add roles like those granted for SAP_PAPM_ADMIN default plan by default, you may visit this, Database Role PAPM_OPERATOR_ROLE to check the roles. 

Below is a sample step on how you can perform the granting of roles:

 a.    Create PAPM_OPERATOR_ROLE example:

CREATE ROLE PAPM_OPERATOR_ROLE;

b.   Using the information in Database Role PAPM_OPERATOR_ROLE, perform the following SQL, example:

GRANT CATALOG READ TO PAPM_OPERATOR_ROLE;

To verify you may check in the Database the Role Management section in Database.

Do this for all the succeeding grants.

c.   Once done, assign this role to the SAP_PAPM_ADMIN like user which can be found in database settings, example:

GRANT PAPM_OPERATOR_ROLE TO SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_<TENANTID>_<UNIQUEID>;

Technical schemas on Standalone HCDB BYOD plan

For you to have an idea with how you can understand the naming convention of schema available after BYOD subscription, refer to the screenshot and table below.

Model

Default Subscription

BYOD Subscription

Standard Model

SAP_PAPM

SAP_PAPM_SM_<TENANTID> is the schema where all artifacts from Standard Model can be found

Standard Model

SAP_PAPM_ADMIN

SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_<TENANTID>_<UNIQUEID>_RT is the database username in Database Settings 

Universal Model

SAP_PAPM_UM

SAP_PAPM_UM_<TENANTID> is the schema where all artifacts from Universal Model can be found

Standard Model

Following the procedures added in the help portal Connections, you may start performing Inbound and Outbound scenarios for Standard Model given by the steps below.

Inbound Scenarios

Accessing artifacts from External SAP HANA Cloud schema

Your existing schema can be used as an Authoring schema on one of the connections in SAP PAPM Cloud to be used for consumption.

Initially, if you are going to create a Connection in Connection Management screen, your schema is not yet visible to be used as expected.

This is because we need to grant a privilege to the technical schema of SAP PAPM Cloud Standard Model which is the equivalent of SAP_PAPM schema.

  1. With this, you need to login on your Standalone HCDB using your external schema credentials using the syntax below:
‚ÄãCONNECT DBMEMBER PASSWORD <‚ÄùPassword‚Äù>;

      2. Once logged in, perform the SQL syntax below to perform the granting of privileges to the technical schema of your SAP PAPM Cloud Standard Model.

GRANT SELECT ON SCHEMA "DBMEMBER" TO <SAP_PAPM_SM_<TenantID>;

This SQL statement above is performed for your external schema to appear in the list of schema on the creation of HANA connection.

    3. After granting of privileges, you can now go back to your Connection Management Screen and your external schema will be available, then you can choose the artifact you prefer. For example, see image below:

The created connection will be eligible for usage in Modeling and from here, we can now successfully consume the table from your existing external schema.

Disclaimer: Data records used on the image above are all dummy and just to show the successful modeling after the granting of privileges.

Outbound Scenarios

Expose SAP PAPM Cloud Standard Model artifacts to external SAP HANA Cloud schema.

If you will be needing the artifacts from SAP PAPM Cloud Standard Model to be read by your external SAP HANA Cloud schema, you may follow the procedure below.

  1. Login on your SAP HANA Cloud Database using your SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_XXXXX_YYYYY_RT as this user refers to SAP_PAPM_ADMIN like schema which is default database user available after subscription.
‚ÄãCONNECT <SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_<TenantID>_<UniqueID>_RT PASSWORD <‚ÄùPassword‚Äù>;

       2. Once logged in as the SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_XXXXX_YYYYY_RT user, you may now perform the below SQL Statement syntax to grant the privilege to available artifacts to external schema:

GRANT SELECT ON SCHEMA ‚ÄúSAP_PAPM_SM_<TenantID>‚Äù TO ‚Äú<ExternalUser>;‚Äã

This SQL Statement above will allow the external schema to perform a read on y-tables available in SAP PAPM Cloud SM.

SAP_PAPM_SM_<XXXX> refers to schema where the generated artifacts of Standard Model are located. This is similar to the SAP_PAPM schema of default plan.

Writing from SAP PAPM Cloud Standard Model to External SAP HANA Cloud Schema

Using the Writer function, SAP PAPM Cloud Standard Model can write back to your external SAP HANA Cloud schema. This will be needing additional grants other than select, depending on the Writer type you will be using.

For example, if the required privilege is not yet granted, you will get an error like the image below:

To avoid these kinds of errors, you may follow the procedure below.

  1. Login to your SAP HANA Cloud Database using your external schema credentials.
CONNECT DBMEMBER PASSWORD <‚ÄùPassword‚Äù>; ‚Äã

       2. In order for Writer Type to perform Insert , using the credentials of your own external schema , execute the SQL statement below :

GRANT INSERT ON SCHEMA DBMEMBER TO <SAP_PAPM_SM_<TenantID>>;‚Äã

       3. In order for Writer Type to perform Delete and Insert , using the credentials of your own external schema , execute the SQL statement below

GRANT INSERT ON SCHEMA DBMEMBER TO <SAP_PAPM_SM_<TenantID>>;
GRANT DELETE ON SCHEMA DBMEMBER TO <SAP_PAPM_SM_<TenantID>>;

SAP_PAPM_SM_<TenantID> refers to schema where the generated artifacts of Standard Model are located. This is similar to the SAP_PAPM schema of default plan.

Universal Model

Following the procedures added in the help portal Manage Connections, you may start performing Inbound and Outbound scenarios for Universal Model given by the steps below.

Inbound Scenarios

Accessing artifacts from External SAP HANA Cloud schema

Your existing external SAP HANA Cloud schema can be used as the Target HANA Schema on your connection in your Universal Model.

Still using the DBMEMBER used from Standard Model scenarios, initially, if you are going to create a Connection in Manage Connection screen, your schema is not yet visible to be used as expected.

This is because we need to grant a privilege to the technical schema of SAP PAPM Cloud Universal Model.

  1. With this, you need to login on your Standalone HCDB using your external user credentials using the syntax below:
CONNECT DBMEMBER PASSWORD <‚ÄùPassword‚Äù>;‚Äã

      2. Once logged in, perform the SQL Statement syntax below:

GRANT SELECT ON SCHEMA DBMEMBER TO "SAP_PAPM_UM_<TenantID>::external_privileges_role" WITH GRANT OPTION;‚Äã

This SQL statement above is performed for your external schema to appear in the list of schema on the creation of HANA Schema connection.

However, on the saving of creation of connection, you will encounter and error like the image below:

With this, you will be needing to perform another grant of privilege to the technical schema of Universal Model which you can refer to the syntax below:

GRANT SELECT ON SCHEMA DBMEMBER TO "SAP_PAPM_UM_<TenantID>#OO" WITH GRANT OPTION;

Once the granting of privileges is done, you may now perform the mapping on your available Model from Target HANA Schema, Activate the Environment and then go to Show data screen to validate the table.

Writing to SAP PAPM Cloud Universal Model artifacts (Z-tables) from External SAP HANA Cloud schema

SAP PAPM Cloud Universal Model supports Data lifecycle Management, therefore, authorized external SAP HANA Cloud schema can perform writing to existing artifacts(Z-tables).

On the subscription of SAP PAPM Cloud, only Database Administrator has the capability to grant the role collection external_access_role. This role collection consists of select, insert, update and delete privileges.

Adding ‚Äú#‚Äù on the role collection external_access_role# will add a Grant option that will let the user give the same privileges to other users.

  1. Login on your SAP HANA Cloud Database using your Database Admin user.
CONNECT DBADMIN PASSWORD <‚ÄùPassword‚Äù>;‚Äã

      2. Once logged in as the DBADMIN, you may now perform the SQL Statement below to grant your _RT user for external access role.

GRANT "SAP_PAPM_UM_<TenantID>"."external_access_role#" TO SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_<TenantID>::external_privileges_role WITH ADMIN OPTION ‚Äã

Note:
external_access_role# role gives read access to the whole ${PAPM_UM} schema and write access to Z tables (Z_* tables) located within the Universal Model schema.

After the run of SQL Statement syntax above, SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_<TenantID>_<UniqueID>_RT schema will have a Grant option that means it can provide the same role to other user.

      3. Login again on your SAP HANA Cloud Database using your SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_<XXXXX>_<YYYYY>_RT user.

CONNECT SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_<TenantID>_<UniqueID>_RT PASSWORD <‚ÄùPassword‚Äù>;‚Äã

      4. As SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_<XXXXX>_<YYYYY>_RT user, grant back DBADMIN the power to give access to your SAP_PAPM_UM_<XXXXX> by following the SQL statement below.

GRANT "SAP_PAPM_UM_<TenantID>"."external_access_role#" TO DBADMIN WITH ADMIN OPTION‚Äã

Note:
external_access_role# role gives read access to the whole ${PAPM_UM} schema and write access to Z tables (Z_* tables) located within the Universal Model schema.

Since SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_<TenantID>_<UniqueID>_RT schema has the Grant option granted from Step 2, we can Grant back the role SAP_PAPM_UM_<TenantID>"."external_access_role#"  to Database Administrator so that it will be able to Grant the role collection to other users.

     5. Login again on your SAP HANA Cloud Database using your DBADMIN user.

CONNECT DBADMIN PASSWORD <‚ÄùPassword‚Äù>;‚Äã

     6. As DBADMIN user, perform the granting of privileges on a specific artifact from SAP PAPM UM by following the SQL Statement below:

GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON SAP_PAPM_UM_<TenantID>.<Z_METABLE> TO <ExternalUser>;‚Äã

Since Database Administrator has now external_access_role#. It can now grant privileges to other users to specific artifacts based on its use cases.
You may also perform a Revoke as Database Administrator that will remove the privileges to your _RT user so that only DBADMIN can manage the granting of privileges to SAP_PAPM_UM_<TenantID> objects.

REVOKE

"SAP_PAPM_UM_<TenantID>"."external_access_role#" FROM "SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_<XXXXX>_<YYYYY>_RT";


For more information, see REVOKE Statement (Access Control).

Outbound Scenarios

Expose Z table entries to external SAP HANA Cloud schema

Follow the procedure outlined below to allow access to your SAP PAPM UM artifacts, such as z-tables and views, from your external SAP HANA Cloud schema:

  1. Login on your SAP HANA Cloud Database using your SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_XXXXX_YYYYY_RT as this user refers to SAP_PAPM_ADMIN like schema which is default database user available after subscription.
    <XXXXX> is equal to Tenant ID of the subaccount minus the hyphen.
    <YYYYY> is a random GUID unique for the tenant.

    This SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_TenantID_UniqueID info can be seen from Hamburger Menu > Administration > Setings. Once you have the credentials, you can follow the SQL Statement syntax below:
CONNECT <SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_TenandID_UniqueID_RT PASSWORD <‚ÄùPassword‚Äù>;

       2. Once logged in as the SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_XXXXX_YYYYY_RT user, you may now perform the below SQL Statement syntax to grant the privilege to available artifacts to external schema:

GRANT SELECT ON SCHEMA ‚ÄúSAP_PAPM_UM_<TenantID>‚Äù TO ‚Äú<ExternalUser>;‚Äã

This SQL Statement above will allow the external schema to perform a read on z-tables available in SAP PAPM Cloud UM

SAP_PAPM_UM_<TenantID> refers to schema where the generated artifacts of Universal Model are located. This is similar to the SAP_PAPM_UM schema of default plan.

Writing from SAP PAPM Cloud Universal Model to External SAP HANA Cloud Schema

Follow the procedure outlined below to enable the SAP PAPM Universal Model to perform write operations, such as inserting or deleting data in the tables of your external schema using the Writer Function:

Procedure:

  1. Login on your SAP HANA Cloud Database using your external schema credentials.
CONNECT <ExternaUser> PASSWORD <‚ÄùPassword‚Äù>;‚Äã

      2. In order for Writer Type to perform Insert, using the credentials of your own external schema , execute the SQL statement below :

GRANT INSERT ON SCHEMA <ExternalUser> TO SAP_PAPM_UM_<TenantID>#OO;‚Äã

      3. In order for Writer Type to perform Delete and Insert, using the credentials of your own external schema , execute the SQL statement below

GRANT DELETE, INSERT ON SCHEMA <ExternalUser> TO SAP_PAPM_UM_<TenantID>#OO;‚Äã

We are done! I hope all scenarios above will be useful for Administration of your BYOD plan using the Standalone SAP HANA Cloud.

You may also refer to our official documentation on:

  • Standard Model Administration of BYOD Plan on Standalone HANA Cloud Database
  • Universal Model Administration of BYOD Plan on Standalone HANA Cloud Database

Stay tune for the part 2 of this blog post where we will discuss how we can Administer BYOD plan of SAP PAPM Cloud .

Bye for now!

entry.title: Re: Handling units with MTO: Sales order to be filled aut...
entry.content:
In REM, the system typically works with run schedule quantities and production versions, not directly with sales orders. Even though you‚Äôve linked the HU to the sales order during packing (via MFP1), MFHU doesn‚Äôt automatically inherit that reference during backflush. The MFHU transaction is designed to backflush based on HU and material, not necessarily the sales order context unless explicitly provided.

So what you can try is to explore implicit enhancements in the MFHU program (SAPLVHURM) to auto-populate the sales order field. Use a lookup based on HU number to retrieve the linked sales order and inject it into the backflush screen.

entry.title: Re: Project purchasing with stock management
entry.content:
Procurement for Stock (J45) is the preferred approach if you want to manage inventory and later consume it for project purposes because,

  1. Stock materials are procured and stored in inventory
  2. No account assignment is needed at the time of purchase.
  3. You can later issue the stock to a WBS element or project using a goods issue transaction.
  4. This allows valuation and quantity tracking in the material master and supports project cost control via stock consumption.

Recommended Best Practice is to use valuated project stock if you're working with projects with revenue. Materials are reserved and consumed only by the assigned project/WBS element

Procurement for Direct Consumption (BNX) is suitable when materials are not stored but consumed immediately upon receipt. Requires account assignment in the purchase order (e.g., cost center, WBS element). No inventory is created; the value is directly expensed. Works well for services, non-stock items, or one-time consumables. Most importantly, the limitations here is You lose visibility into stock levels and cannot reuse materials across projects.

entry.title: Binding a SAC Custom Widget to Multiple Models Simultaneously
entry.content:
Is it possible to connect a custom widget to more than one model at the same time? I'm developing a custom widget that compares data across models, and it would be highly beneficial to retrieve data directly from these models. Currently, I've implemented a workaround by passing data from hidden tables, each connected to a separate model.

According to the announcement post from 2022:

The keys of the dataBindings property represent the arbitrary name of the dataBinding, and contains a "feeds" property which is an array of objects that define a "feed". Currently this is limited to defining one dataBinding object. Defining multiples will not yield any error but only the first one will be used.

As far as I can tell, this limitation still applies. Are there any plans to support multiple dataBindings in the future?

Cheers,
≈Åukasz

entry.title: Re: SAP ABAP RAP - Missing value on UI after data created
entry.content:
Hi @yoppie_aries 

In unmanaged RAP, after persisting your new record, you must fill the result table that SAP UI5 consumes.

as an example :

APPEND VALUE #( %cid         = booking_data-%cid
                booking_id   = <your created ID>
                travel_id    = <your travel ID>
                customer_id  = <your customer>
                ... other fields ...
              ) TO result.

please make sure all necessary fields are filled. Otherwise, UI will not show the created data even though it exists in DB.

entry.title: Getting Started with SAP Open Connectors
entry.content:
Introduction to SAP Open Connectors

In today‚Äôs fast-paced digital landscape, seamless integration across various systems and applications is crucial for business success. SAP Open Connectors, a key capability within the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), is designed to simplify and accelerate this process.

SAP Open Connectors offers a unified API integration layer that streamlines connectivity to over 160 third-party cloud applications, including popular platforms like Salesforce, Microsoft Dynamics, Google services, and more.

Instead of building and maintaining individual connectors for each application, Open Connectors provides prebuilt connectors with standardized APIs, helping developers avoid the complexity of dealing with diverse authentication methods, pagination formats, error handling, and data models.

Assign Roles in BTP

  • OpenConnectorsAdmin
  • OpenConnectorsUser
  • OpenConnectorsDeveloper

    Prerequisites:

    • SAP BTP account (Open Connectors supports trial accounts)

      Demonstrate on how to connect Gmail API Connector

      Firstly, Add the capabilities for Open Connectors on the Integration Suite. After that, we should assign the role related to Open Connectors.

      Step 1: Integration suite Home page >> Capabilities >> Manage Capabilities. Click on ‚ÄúManage Capabilities‚Äù.

      Step 2: Click on ‚ÄúAdd Capabilities‚Äù

      Step 3: Click on check box i.e., Extend Non-Sap Connectivity

      Step 4: After the above step, you will see the below mentioned in Home Page. Click on ‚ÄúCreate Connectors‚Äù. After this step, you will be navigate to Open Connectors Home Page.

      Open Connectors Configuration

      Now, we will be working on Gmail Connector. After navigating to Open Connectors Home Page. You will be able to see the below page. Just, Search for the Gmail in search box.  

      Connectors >> Gmail >> My Resources (place the cursor in Gmail connector, then only you can see the Resources) >> Authenticate Instance.

      I am creating an instance with the name of ‚ÄúDemoGmail‚Äù.

      After this step, you will be redirected to a different page or click this url 

      • https://console.cloud.google.com/

        Get Gmail OAuth Credentials 

        • Create a new project or use existing
        • Click on "Select a project".

          Give Project Name as Your wish. e.g. My Project - 1 >> Click on "Create".In the search bar, type Gmail API >> Click on Gmail API >> Click Enable.

          After enabling your API, you will be redirect to another page.

          This Step: Create OAuth Client Credentials

          Click on Create Credentials

          Click on "Configure consent screen".

          Click on "Get Started" which is highlighted in blue color.

          Give all the details

          App name: Test

          User support email: "Give your mail id e.g. xxxx@gmail.com"

          Choose "External"

          Contact Information: Give your mail id

          Click "Agree" checkbox >> Continue >> Create

          When you have this page, click on "Create OAuth client".

          Fill the details as mentioned in below Image.

          Skip "Authorized JavaScript origins"

          In "Authorized redirect URIs", Click "Add URI" >> give the urI as mentioned in below image >> Click on "Create". 

          Download your credentials by clicking on Download JSON or else you can copy & paste in your notepad. Click on OK.

          Go to Hamburger button which is located on Top Left side. You can see API & Services as shown in below image. click on it.

          API & Services >> Credentials >> Audience >> Add Users (add your mail id) >> click on "Save".

           Data Access >> Add or remove scopes >> add below scopes >> add to table >> click on update.

          https://www.googleapis.com/auth/gmail.send

          https://www.googleapis.com/auth/gmail.readonly

          https://www.googleapis.com/auth/gmail.modify

          Navigate to your open connectors, give your client credentials, create instance.

          You will see the below page with success popup.

          Click on Test in the API docs

          GET: Retrieves data or resources from the server (ex: fetch mail messages). Follow the below images highlighted with red rectangle. 

          When you're complete your execution, if no errors you will get 200 message.

entry.title: Re: Session 2 Recap & Highlights‚Äì Unleash your Data and AI with Irfan Khan and Timo Elliott
entry.content:
Thank you for this session. It helps clarify what a data product is.

One important foundational topic that is going to get even more important in the future is for clients to get the  organisation design in ERP right. In the past a lot of clients implemented ECC with 'custom' use of key fields such as business area, profit center, or perhaps having unusual use cases for accounts and cost centers. Just this week, there was a post in the group about a client looking at using business area for something which should be a profit center.

With all the effort to provide this semantic data in reporting, I think clients should want to stick to standard usage of fields even more than before.

I appreciate the example of Company Code, I took a look on api.sap.com and saw there were several key finance fields already there: leger, profit center, cost center, account etc. It's useful to be able to browse the JSON

https://api.sap.com/dataproduct/sap-s4com-CompanyCode-v1/overview

During the presentation I tried to capture informal notes on Irfan's summary of the architecture and the development/consumption flow. Perhaps I can check my understanding?

So for the hierarchy, I sketched out the below. Our 'golden source of truth' is the HANA DB, which feeds CDS views which then feed the data product in DataSphere. The data product gets all the annotations from the CDS views, but possibly may have more added during it's design?

 

And in terms of the flow of design, deploy and consume, I sketched it out like the below:

  1. We start with the basic data design which really comes from CDS design then data product design
  2. Then we have the push pipeline which is really two steps, extract from ERP, then replication to BDC datalake
  3. Then it's fully managed ongoing (presumably triggered by events in ERP etc.)
  4. Then it's ready to be consumed by apps / reports etc.

Loving the direction of 'open approach' and also the goal to eliminate ETL effort.

On the topic of data quality. I do think there isn't enough focus on helping clients get their data model right at the point of design/implementation of ERP. There are still clients and consultants citing incorrect definitions of basic fields every day. I think the problem is, it's not particularly exciting, but definitely an area that still needs focus.

My first ever role back 2000 was cleaning 120,000 vendors for an R/2 to R/3 migration! So fun.

We had a similar issue , data was not being released by the Release task. We also noticed that any new journals we created didn't contain any values in the Consolidation relevant fields (Consol Unit, FS Item, etc.) in ACDOCA. We resolved this with this note: 3317403 - GRPL: Substitution is not working - SAP for Me

We then ran a realignment run which updated the consolidation fields in ACDOCA, afterwards the release task worked correctly.

Check if newly created journals have these fields populated or not, this note would resolve it.

Regards

Finbar

entry.title: Designing a Fiori-Ready CDS View with UI Facets, Value Helps, and Associations in RAP
entry.content:
Introduction 

In this blog post, I will explain how to design a CDS view entity in ABAP RAP (RESTful ABAP Programming Model) that is well-suited for use with Fiori Elements. We'll use annotations such as ui.facet, Consumption.valueHelpDefinition, ObjectModel.association, and search.defaultSearchElement to enhance the user interface and behavior.

The example is based on a Flight Management scenario, where we create a CDS view to manage flight connections and set up associations to carrier and flight-related data.

Use Case

  • Display flight connection details as the header, along with the related flight entries as line items

  • Provide value help functionality for airport-related fields

  • Use associations to link the CDS view to related entities such as carrier and airport information

  • Enable search capabilities and ensure the data is optimized for Fiori Elements

CDS View Entity Code 

ZPS_FLIGHT_R - Flight Information 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE] 
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED 
@EndUserText.label: 'Flight Information' 
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true 
@ObjectModel.usageType:{ 
serviceQuality: #X, 
sizeCategory: #S, 
dataClass: #MIXED 
} 
@Search.searchable: true 
define view entity ZPS_FLIGHT_R 
as select from /dmo/flight 
association[1] to ZPS_CARRIER_R as _Airline on $projection.CarrierId = _Airline.CarrierId  
{ 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 10 }] 
@ObjectModel.text.association: '_Airline' 
key carrier_id as CarrierId, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 20 }] 
key connection_id as ConnectionId, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 30 }] 
key flight_date as FlightDate, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 40 }] 
@Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'CurrencyCode' 
price as Price, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 50 }] 
currency_code as CurrencyCode, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 60 }] 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
plane_type_id as PlaneTypeId, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 70 }] 
seats_max as SeatsMax, 
@UI.lineItem: [{ position: 80 }] 
seats_occupied as SeatsOccupied, 
_Airline 
}

ZPS_CARRIER_R - Carrier detail 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE] 
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED 
@EndUserText.label: 'Carrier detail' 
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true 
@ObjectModel.usageType:{ 
serviceQuality: #X, 
sizeCategory: #S, 
dataClass: #MIXED 
} 
@Search.searchable: true 
define view entity ZPS_CARRIER_R 
as select from /dmo/carrier 
{ 
key carrier_id as CarrierId, 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
@Semantics.text: true 
@Search.fuzzinessThreshold: 0.8 
name as Name, 
currency_code as CurrencyCode 
}

ZPS_AIRPORT_VH - Value help for airport 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE] 
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED 
@EndUserText.label: 'Value help for airport' 
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true 
@ObjectModel.usageType:{ 
serviceQuality: #X, 
sizeCategory: #S, 
dataClass: #MIXED 
} 
@Search.searchable: true 
define view entity ZPS_AIRPORT_VH 
as select from /dmo/airport 
{ 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
key airport_id as AirportId, 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
@Search.fuzzinessThreshold: 0.7 
name as Name, 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
@Search.fuzzinessThreshold: 0.7 
city as City, 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
@Search.fuzzinessThreshold: 0.7 
country as Country 
}

ZPS_CONNECTION_FLIGHT - Flight Reference 

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE] 
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED 
@EndUserText.label: 'Flight Reference' 
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true 
@ObjectModel.usageType:{ 
serviceQuality: #X, 
sizeCategory: #S, 
dataClass: #MIXED 
} 
@UI.headerInfo: { 
typeName: 'Connection', 
typeNamePlural: 'Connections' 
} 
@Search.searchable: true 
define view entity ZPS_CONNECTION_FLIGHT 
as select from /dmo/connection as connection 
association [1..*] to ZPS_FLIGHT_R as _flight on $projection.CarrierId = _flight.CarrierId 
and $projection.ConnectionId = _flight.ConnectionId 
association [1] to ZPS_CARRIER_R as _Airline on $projection.CarrierId = _Airline.CarrierId 
{ 
@UI.facet: [{ id: 'Connection', 
purpose: #STANDARD, 
type: #IDENTIFICATION_REFERENCE, 
position: 10, 
label: 'Connection Detail' }, 
{ id: 'Flight', 
purpose: #STANDARD, 
type: #LINEITEM_REFERENCE, 
position: 20, 
label: 'Flights', 
targetElement: '_flight' 
} 
] 
@UI.lineItem: [{position: 10, label: 'Airline' }] 
@UI.identification: [{ position: 10, label: 'Airline' }] 
@ObjectModel.text.association: '_Airline' 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
key carrier_id as CarrierId, 
@UI.lineItem: [{position: 20 }] 
@UI.identification: [{ position: 20 }] 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
key connection_id as ConnectionId, 
@UI.selectionField: [{ position: 10 }] 
@UI.lineItem: [{position: 30, label: 'Depature Airport Id' }] 
@UI.identification: [{ position: 30, label: 'Depature Airport Id' }] 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
@Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{ entity:{ 
name: 'ZPS_AIRPORT_VH', 
element: 'AirportId'} }] 
airport_from_id as AirportFromId, 
@UI.selectionField: [{ position: 20 }] 
@UI.lineItem: [{position: 40 }] 
@UI.identification: [{ position: 40 }] 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
@Consumption.valueHelpDefinition: [{ entity:{ 
name: 'ZPS_AIRPORT_VH', 
element: 'AirportId'} }] 
@EndUserText.label: 'Destination Airport ID' 
airport_to_id as AirportToId, 
@UI.lineItem: [{position: 50, label: 'Departure Time' }] 
@UI.identification: [{ position: 50 }] 
departure_time as DepartureTime, 
@UI.lineItem: [{position: 60, label: 'Arrival Time' }] 
@UI.identification: [{ position: 60 }] 
arrival_time as ArrivalTime, 
@Semantics.quantity.unitOfMeasure: 'DistanceUnit' 
@UI.identification: [{ position: 70 }] 
distance as Distance, 
distance_unit as DistanceUnit, 
//Association--> 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
_flight, 
@Search.defaultSearchElement: true 
_Airline 

}

Key Concepts Covered

Annotations
ui.facet : Creates grouped sections in the Fiori Object Page
ui.lineItem : Controls the display of fields in table lists
Consumption.valueHelpDefinit : Enables F4 value help for fields
search.defaultSearchElement : Makes the field available in the Fiori search bar
ObjectModel.text.association : Provides text description for key fields
Association to entity Enables : navigation and linking to related entities

You‚Äôll see: 

  • A header section labeled "Connection Detail" displaying the main connection information

  • A "Flights" section or tab, enabled through the _flight association, showing related flight entries as line items

  • F4 help (value help) activated for airport_from_id and airport_to_id fields using @Consumption.valueHelpDefinition

  • A search bar that allows filtering by fields such as Airline, Connection ID, Departure Airport, and Destination Airport

     

Departure airport value help

Line-item record

Summary 

This blog demonstrated how to build a Fiori-optimized CDS view using ABAP RAP, with the help of UI annotations, value helps, and text associations.

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and Central Finance
entry.content:
Hello @Lena_Schmidt 

Thanks for your message.

Please note that SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition does not support SLT (SAP Landscape Transformation) replication as either a source or target system. The S4 HANA public cloud architecture does not allow database-level access or trigger-based replication, which SLT requires via the LTRC transaction. This limitation includes Central Finance (CFIN) scenarios where SLT is typically used to replicate transactional data.

For data integration with S/4HANA Public Cloud, SAP only supports communication via standard APIs (SOAP, OData) or event-based messaging using technologies like SAP Cloud Integration or Event Mesh. These are the officially supported and secure channels for connecting external systems.

If your use case depends on SLT or Central Finance, S/4HANA Public Cloud is currently not a suitable deployment model.
Please check this SAP help documentation Integration Guides Overview 

Let me know if you need further support

entry.title: Settlement of Investment Projects in SAP Cloud ERP
entry.content:
What is Project Settlement?

Settlement is the process of transferring costs incurred on a project to a final receiver such as:

  • an asset under construction
  • a completed fixed asset
  • or a cost object (e.g. cost center)

In the context of capital investment projects, this ensures the capital expenditures (CapEx) are properly posted to the balance sheet instead of the P&L.

To start with a simplified view, we can split the complete process into two parts:

Asset Creation Phase

  • settlement moves costs from the investment project to asset(s) under construction

  • this can be done via periodic settlement at the close of the period or event-based with every posting to the investment project

Final Asset available to be used

  • settlement moves balance sheet values from asset(s) under construction to final asset 
    values that cannot be capitalised can be moved to other cost objects, e.g. cost centers

  • this is done via periodic settlement at the close of the period

 

Master Data Involved

Investment Projects are used primarily for planning and monitoring capital investments that are not capitalised directly, due to their scope or the large percentage of in-house production involved.

  • All expenditures related to the investment project are tracked separately to differentiate them from regular operational costs.
    This can include materials, labor, and overheads.
  • The account assignment object for actual posting is always the investment project/ WBS element.
  • Investment projects are relevant for asset accounting this is why they have an asset under construction (AuC) assigned.

Assets Under Construction refer to the work-in-progress phase where a company is finalising the development or acquisition of long-term assets (like a building or a piece of machinery).

  • Costs related to the asset under construction are recorded in an asset under construction/ capital work-in-process account on the balance sheet. This account accumulates all expenditures until the asset is ready for its intended use.
  • The asset under construction is included in the asset history sheet and keeps detailed records of all costs related to investment projects for audit and regulatory purposes.
  • Once the construction is completed and the asset is ready for use, the total accumulated costs in the asset under construction account are transferred to the appropriate fixed asset account on the balance sheet.

 

Lifecycle of the Investment Project

SAP provides standard capabilities to manage the entire lifecycle of an investment project:

  1. Project Creation
    initiated via the app Project Control - Enterprise Projects
  2. Cost Collection
    Costs from procurement, time recording, and service are collected on the investment project WBS (work breakdown structure) elements
  3. Asset Under Construction (AuC) Creation
    Automatically created when the project is released. Make sure you are using the project profile Investment Project.
  4. Periodic or Event-Based Settlement
    Periodic jobs can be scheduled via the app Schedule Overhead Accounting Jobs. For processing of single investment projects, you can use Run Settlement ‚Äì Actual.
    With release CE2508 a new functionality Event-based Settlement to AuC is available. Using event-based settlement makes the periodic settlement process obsolete as all costs are settled immediately when posted to the investment project.
  5. Final Settlement and Asset Capitalisation
    Upon project completion, costs are settled to the final fixed asset. Costs that cannot be capitalised can be settled to other cost objects (e.g. cost centers).

 

How Project Settlement Works

1. Settlement to Asset under Construction (AuC)
  • periodic settlement: with the first settlement the rule to AuC gets automatically created (settlement type AUC)
    PRE rules can be used to make sure non-capitalisable costs are not posted to the AuC.
  • event-based settlement: 100% of the costs will be settled to AuC, rules for preliminary settlement (PRE rules) are not supported, no AUC settlement rule is needed.
    Event-based settlement is a new functionality made available with CE2508. It can be activated in the investment profile (for details on configuration see dedicated chapter).

2. Settlement to Final Asset

When the project is completed and the asset can be used, the AuC is cleared and costs are capitalised to the final asset.

  • The status of the investment project will be changed to technically completed. With this status the system carries out full settlement (distribution rules of type ‚Äúfull settlement‚Äù are used)
  • in the event-based scenario the final settlement will post to final receiver per line item, enabling the feature ‚Äúlist of origins reporting‚Äù for the AuC and the final asset
  • the processing type ‚Äúpartial capitalisation‚Äù can be used for a partial settlement to fixed asset/ other cost object, before the investment project is technically completed.

 

Settlement Rules

Define the receivers which could be AuC, final asset, or other cost objects.
Rules can be defined as percentages/ equivalences or amounts. Each rule comes with a validity period.

  • Full Settlement (FUL)
    • all costs posted to the sender, also costs in prior periods are settled
    • ensures a balance of zero even if late postings to prior period occur
    • these rules are used for final settlements to the fixed asset,
      or they can be used for partial capitalisation if values shall be moved out of the asset under construction before the asset is finished
  • Preliminary Settlement (PRE)
    PRE rules are used during settlement to AuC (preliminary settlement), if part of the costs shall not be activated on AuC
    > not available with event-based settlement
  • Settlement to AuC (AUC)
    with periodic settlement these rules are automatically created with the first settlement, the receiver is the AuC

Examples for different settlement/ distribution rules:

line 1 shows a rule for settlement from AuC to cost object that can be used with processing type ‚ÄúPartial Capitalisation‚Äù
such rules need to be valid for one period only (from/to = identical)

line 2 +3 show rules for settlement to fixed asset (final settlement)

line 4 shows a rule for settlement to AuC (preliminary settlement)
> not supported with event-based settlement

 

Period End Closing - Settlement Run

 

Event Based Settlement (new CE2508)

 

Ledger Specific Settlement Rules

  •  Ledger-Specific Settlement                                                 
    • values to be settled will be calculated per ledger 
    • always active in SAP Cloud ERP  
  • Ledger-Specific Settlement Rules
    • settlement rules can be defined per ledger
    • optional, needs to be activated in settlement profile

Possible Use Case
Settlements to assets under construction/ final asset shall be done according to different GAAPs, e.g. German GAAP defines that 70% of construction costs can be activated while US-GAAP allows for activation of 80% of construction costs.

 

Key Configuration Elements

  • Project Profile
    Project profiles are pre-delivered in the public cloud edition and cannot be configured. make sure you are using profile Investment Project to enable the integration to asset management
  • Settlement Profile
    Determines whether the settlement is allowed and to which receiver type.
  • Asset Class & Number Ranges
    Defines the type of asset created (e.g. building, machinery).
  • Investment Profile
    Used to configure the asset class for the asset under construction. You can also define if you want to have just one AuC created per WBS element, or if you need several AuC for one WBS element.
    The option for event-based settlement is also activated in the investment profile.

 

Benefits of Project Settlement in SAP Cloud ERP

  • Transparency: Clearly track investment costs and their capitalisation status
  • Automation: Reduce manual tasks with predefined rules and scheduled jobs
  • Compliance: Aligns with IFRS and local GAAP requirements
  • Audit Readiness: Comprehensive documentation of all postings and asset movements

Additional Benefits with Event-Based Settlements

  • Transparency: with event-based settlement postings are moved line item by line item throughout the complete settlement process from the project to the AuC and to the final asset.
  • Automation: as the first settlement step ‚ÄúProject 2 AuC‚Äù is done event-based, no manual interaction or job scheduling is needed any longer
  • Compliance: the line item details will still be available for the final asset. With this level of detail it is very easy to explain the asset value as for each posting can navigated back to the initial project posting. This kind of reporting is even available without using line item settlement.

entry.title: EWM Queue Error ‚ÄúField Item: Batch Number is a require field for the action HDR: PDO save Document"
entry.content:
In this blog, queues which are failed due to error message "Field Item: Batch Number is a require field for the action HDR: PDO save Document" will be resolved with step by step approach.

Issue Overview:

An Inbound Delivery is created without a batch number for a material which is maintained as batch-managed in material master.
Upon saving the delivery, its status changes to ‚ÄúB‚Äù (Distributed).As a result, an EWM inbound queue error occurs with the message:

‚ÄúField Item: Batch Number is a required field for the action HDR: PDO Save Document Header.‚Äù

Steps to replicate the Issue:

Step 1:
Check in.material master to confirm that the material is batch-managed.

 

Step2:

The Inbound delivery as displayed in the below screenshot is created without batch

 

Step3:

On Saving the delivery, header status - Dec Whse for the delivery is changed to ‚ÄúB‚Äù (Distributed).

 

The EWM Error queue error occurs with the message as ‚ÄúField Item: Batch Number is a require field for the action HDR: PDO save Document Header‚Äù

 

 

Solution to resolve the EWM Queue:

Step1:

To resolve this , intial step is to save the queue with error using the transaction code SMQ2.

 

Step2:

From transaction code SE37, execute FM (Function Module) :  /SPE/DELV_RESET_DIST_STATUS

 

Once executed - this will reset the delivery‚Äôs distribution status from "B" (Distributed) to "A" (Relevant).

 

 

 

 

 Step3:

Delivery is now open and can be changes - hence a new batch can be created or assigned for the line items in the inbound delivery.

 

Step4:

Once completed - save S4 inbound delivery to  re-trigger the distribution to EWM, with updated batch information included, to process queues sucessfully.

 

Conclusion:

Provided  solution resolves EWM queue error ‚ÄúField Item: Batch Number is a required field for the action HDR: PDO Save Document Header‚Äù by resetting the distribution status, maintaining batch data, and successfully re-distributing the delivery to EWM.

entry.title: Re: Standard Exception Types for a Custom Reuseable Eleme...
entry.content:
You're correct that within Key User Extensibility (e.g., in Custom Business Objects (CBOs), Custom Logic, or the Cloud ABAP Environment), the RAISE EXCEPTION TYPE statement is permitted. However, the available exception classes are restricted to a safe, whitelisted set provided by SAP.

In the Key User extensibility framework (like in the method YY1_MARITIME_EXPERIENCE=>VOYAGE_ID_DERIVE), the most commonly allowed standard exception classes include:

1. CX_NO_CHECK

  • Root class for exceptions without explicit RAISING declaration.

  • You can inherit from this to create your own custom exceptions (if supported).

2. CX_STATIC_CHECK

  • For exceptions that must be declared in the method signature.

  • Less frequently usable directly unless a method signature explicitly supports it.

3. CX_DYNAMIC_CHECK

  • Runtime-check exceptions (can be raised dynamically).

But in Key User Extensibility, you may not be able to use all of these freely‚ÄîSAP allows only a restricted subset, and you usually cannot define your own global exception classes .

entry.title: Stock Upload in SAP EWM using the Transaction Code /N/SCWM/ISU
entry.content:
Steps to perform for Stock Upload in SAP EWM using the Transaction Code /N/SCWM/ISU

Step 1:
Navigate to ‚ÄúStock Data Transfer‚Äù in the SAP Easy Access menu or directly enter the transaction code /N/SCWM/ISU.

 

 

Step 2:
The Stock Data Transfer screen will appear.
Enter Warehouse Number, and click on the folder icon to select input file.

 

 

Step 3:
Navigate to the upload file as displayed in the screenshot, and select on the Upload button to upload data.

Prompt with the "SAP GUI Security" dialog box will be displayed, check ‚ÄúRemember My Decision‚Äù and click ‚ÄúAllow‚Äù .

 

Step 4:
Uploaded data will be displayed in the highlighted section.

Click the Execute button to process the stock upload.

 

Step 5:
A Warehouse Task will be automatically created for the uploaded stock.

 

 

Step 6:
To verify the uploaded material and quantity, go to transaction /N/SCWM/MON (Warehouse Monitor).

 

Step 7:
In the background, movement type 561 is triggered to post the stock into the ERP system.
You can verify this posting in transaction MB51.

 

Conclusion:

Steps to perform Stock Upload in SAP EWM using the Transaction Code /N/SCWM/ISU is provided.

entry.title: Navigating the BP transaction Authorizations in S/4HANA : SAP Security Experts Guide
entry.content:
General Overview

The Business Partner (BP) transaction is the central tool for managing customer and vendor master data in SAP S/4HANA. For many customers, this represents a transition from older transactions like XK01, FK01, and FD01. This change is part of the core data model redesign in S/4HANA, aimed at consolidating customer and vendor information into a single, unified repository. By doing so, it eliminates data redundancy and streamlines business processes. This approach is often also referred to as Customer-Vendor Integration (CVI).

This shift has many SAP Security consultants scratching their heads. The consolidated transaction called BP in S/4HANA combines functionality from over 60 legacy transactions into one powerful master transaction. While efficient, This simplification introduces a lot of complexity ‚Äî particularly for security.

When you check the SU24 data for the BP transaction, you'll find it can include anywhere from 20 to 80 authorization objects. While this extensive list provides fine-grained control over access‚Äîwhich is great from a security standpoint‚Äîit can also be overwhelming. Assigning the BP transaction to a PFCG role often means suddenly facing the task of maintaining values for 30 or more authorization objects, which few enjoy dealing with.

Another challenge with the BP transaction is that, despite having a large number of authorization objects available to control access, many of these checks are inactive by default. As a result, the transaction appears to offer granular control, but in reality, it lacks many essential authorization checks‚Äîmaking it difficult to enforce precise access restrictions.

If your organization has a central team managing master data, you may not encounter some of the challenges mentioned earlier. However, in scenarios involving geographically distributed teams and decentralized master data management, maintaining effective authorizations for the BP transaction can become a significant issue.

Now that we‚Äôve identified the challenges, let‚Äôs explore how to tackle them. In this blog, I‚Äôll clarify and break down the key authorization objects you can use to manage BP authorizations more effectively.

What all transactions BP replaced

Lets start with the basics, the following transaction codes are no longer available as standalone transactions in the S/4HANA system. You can verify the updated list by checking the PRGN_CORR2 table using transaction SE16 in your system.

  • FD01, FD02, FD03, FD05, FD06, FD08
  • FK01, FK02, FK03, FK05, FK06, FK08
  • MAP1, MAP2, MAP3
  • MK01, MK02, MK03, MK05, MK06, MK12, MK18, MK19
  • V-03, V-04, V-05, V-06, V-07, V-08, V-09, V-11, V+21, V+22, V+23
  • VAP1, VAP2, VAP3
  • VD01, VD02, VD03, VD05, VD06
  • XD01, XD02, XD03, XD05, XD06, XD07
  • XK01, XK02, XK03, XK05, XK06, XK07

It‚Äôs important to note that while you may still assign these transactions to users, executing them in S/4HANA typically redirects the user to the BP transaction, often accompanied by an informational message at the bottom of the screen "Redirecting to transaction BP"

‚ÄÉ

Managing the Authorizations for Business Partner transaction

Just like restricting any other transaction in SAP, restricting BP transactions comes down to the correct restrictions across various authorization objects. We will go through these one by one. Lets start then,

When you Execute the BP transaction you are shown this initial screen(see figure) where you can search for a Business Partner(Customer, Vendor etc) using various criterias.

  • ‚úÖ As expected an initial S_TCODE - checks for start transaction code access happens here. Nothing complicated so far,

Once you select a Business Partner the details of the business partner id displayed(see figure), and a lot of authorization checks happens at this level, this is where things gets complicated as well. Lets look at these one by one :

  • ‚úÖ B_BUPA_RLT Business Partner: BP Roles

This Authorization object controls what BP role a uses has, these BP Role (don't confuse these with PFCG roles) defines what functions a user can perform (ACTVT) and also controls the assignment blocks visible in the BP screen(RLTYP). For example:- If the user selects "Business Partner(Gen.)" Role from the dropdown, it allows editing of basic(general) data of the BP. But if the users switches to a different role "Customer" then some additional tabs will open up where data relevant to cutomers can be maintained.

Although, SAP Delivers some standard BP roles these can still be configured and created in SPRO img configuration by your functional team if need arises.

SPRO ‚Üí Cross-Application Components ‚Üí SAP Business Partner ‚Üí Business Partner ‚Üí Basic Settings ‚Üí Business Partner Roles ‚ÜíDefine BP Roles

Read more about this here - https://me.sap.com/notes/3416144

Next is,

  • ‚úÖ B_BUPA_GRP Business Partner: Authorization Groups

With this authorization object, you define which business partners can be edited on the basis of the authorization groups. Now this authorization is optional and You therefore do not have to assign this authorization if there is no master data requiring special protection.

This groups restrictions require 3 things to work properly -

  1. SPRO configuration which can be done here : SPRO ‚Üí Cross-Application Components ‚Üí SAP Business Partner ‚Üí Business Partner ‚Üí Basic Settings ‚ÜíAuthorization Management -> Maintain Authorization Groups
  2. The group needs to be maintained in master data , this can be done via opening the Business partner in general role, Navigate to the Control tab of the BP screen, then maintaining the Authorization Group here. (see screenshot below)
  3. Include authorization object in the role assinged to the user with restrictions. Read more about this here - https://me.sap.com/notes/3416153

Next,

Based on whether you have opened Customer or Vendor different set of authorization will be checked.

  • For Customer - F_KNA1* authorization objects will be checked.
  • For Vendors - F_LFA1* authorization objects will be checked.

‚úÖ F_KNA1_GEN/ F_LFA1_GEN - This authorization object controls which activities are permitted for the general data. The general data consists of the fields that are independent of the company code and the sales organization. This only has single authorization field for ACTVT

 
‚úÖ F_KNA1_GRP/ F_LFA1_GRP - You use this authorization object to specify which activities are permitted for the individual account groups. The object consists of the "Activity" and "Account Group" fields. Note that this groups is different from the group in - B_BUPA_GRP.
 

‚ÄÉ‚úÖ F_KNA1_APP/ F_LFA1_APP - You use this authorization object to determine which activities are allowed for customer/Vendor master records. The object is defined with the fields "Activity" and "Application authorization".

For all of these F_* authorization objects, You will get suggestion and pressing "F1" on the authorization objects will give you some help. These authorizations objects are well known adn documented.

Other Important Authorization objects

Apart from the major objects mentioned above, some of the other important objects are mentioned below. Most of these can be configured at location - SPRO ‚Üí Cross-Application Components ‚Üí SAP Business Partner ‚Üí Business Partner ‚Üí Basic Settings ‚Üí Authorization Management

 

  • ‚úÖ B_BUPA_ATT - This authorization object is optional and is typically used to restrict users to entering only specific values for certain fields. For Example: Suppose a user should only be allowed to create Business Partners with the country set to India. In this case, you can use this authorization object to ensure the user can only enter "IN" in the country field. Any attempt to use a different country code would be blocked based on this restriction. You can read more about this configuration here: https://me.sap.com/notes/3416118/E
  • ‚úÖ B_BUPA_FDG = Authorization object B_BUPA_FDG on BP is used exclusively for field level customization. The user can enforce authorization on the fields in the BP screen. The user for example can set a particular field on the screen as display only even in the change mode for the business partner. You can read more about this configuration here: https://me.sap.com/notes/3416138/E
  • ‚úÖ B_CCARD = You can use this object to regulate authorization for display and/or maintenance of payment card master data.
  • ‚úÖ B_CCSEC = Use this authorization object to define who can display unmasked credit card numbers and who can evaluate or delete the access logs.
 
Some other authorization objects which control the Sales area and Company code level details of Business Partners are - V_KNA1_VKO, M_LFM1_EKO, F_KNA1_BUK, F_LFA1_BUK etc.

 

Miscelleneous

If you are still struggling with restricting access properly for BP transaction, You may find some of the below helpful :

‚ú≥Ô∏èCreate role with just 1 transaction - BP in it. Infact you can have multiple versions of such roles with various degree of access to the single BP transaction. These roles then can be incorporated into Composite roles for better administration. Your roles will look something like this:

  • ZBP_VENDOR - BP role with access to only Vendor(Supplier) Master Data
  • ZBP_CUSTOMER - BP role with access to only Customer Master Data
  • ZBP_MASTERDATA_ALL - BP role with Full access to both Customers & Vendors
  • ZBP_DISPLAY_ALL - BP role with Display all access

You can follow this helpful guide for role creation - Business Partner Authorization Tips and Tricks

‚ú≥Ô∏èIn SU24, you can set the check indicator for unused authorization objects linked to the BP transaction to "No". For rarely used authorization objects, setting them to "Yes, Inactive Default" helps keep things tidy. This simple step significantly reduces clutter and simplifies role maintenance.

‚ú≥Ô∏èWhen troubleshooting, start by checking the user buffer using transaction SU56. If the user has multiple single roles assigned, they might be receiving access to the relevant authorization object from one of these roles‚Äîeffectively bypassing the intended restrictions on the BP transaction.

‚ú≥Ô∏èEnsure that the authorization object is included in the user's profile‚Äîthis is especially important for optional objects like B_BUPA_FDG, which can be used to restrict access to specific fields within the BP transaction. If this object is not included in the user's role, or if it exists in an inactive state. The system will ignore the restrictions, and the user will have unrestricted access to the field. The system only enforces restrictions if the object is present and active in the user master record.

‚ú≥Ô∏èAlthough rare, there are cases where the SAP system may not behave as expected or fail to respect certain authorization checks‚Äîpotentially due to a system issue on SAP‚Äôs end. We encountered such a scenario where the system was incorrectly checking for activity "05" (Block) on F_LFA1_GRP objects even when simply displaying a Business Partner. SAP acknowledged the issue and provided a correction through an OSS Notes. https://me.sap.com/notes/3097438/E , https://me.sap.com/notes/3093933/E

‚ú≥Ô∏èFor handling complex scenarios or implementing custom logic, you can collaborate with your functional and development teams to explore available BADIs or customer exits that may be leveraged. Refer to the resources below to explore such solutions in more detail:

  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NKlshC0uyyE
  • https://me.sap.com/notes/0002606686
  • https://me.sap.com/notes/2309153
