entry.title: SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration Q2 2025 - What's New?
entry.content:
Q2 2025 has been an exciting quarter for SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration, bringing a rich set of innovations that simplify asset management, enhance data usability, and strengthen collaboration between asset operators, OEMs and service providers. This quarter focuses on advancing master data management, improving work order processes, and expanding integration and API capabilities to support seamless and standardized operations. Whether you're managing material data, processing equipment entry, or working with shared notifications and work orders, these updates are designed to help you work smarter, faster, and more collaboratively across your asset ecosystem.

 

Material Outbound Integration

Scope:

  • Support ERP outbound replication of materials to models between SAP ERP and SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration

Key Benefits:

  • As an asset operator, you can replicate components assigned to work orders and work order operations from SAP ERP to SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration. Consequently, you can share the work order operations with the corresponding components to an external service providers so that the service providers has a complete overview on the work to be performed and the required spare parts.

Description:

  • This feature allows you to perform outbound sync of material data from ERP to models in SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration. The associated material classes, characteristics, characteristic values, and documents are replicated as model templates, attributes, data sheet, and associated documents for the model.

    For more information, see Materials.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Assignment of Components to Work Orders and Work Order Operations

Scope:

  • Assignment of Components for Work Orders & Work Order Operations

Key Benefits:

  • Enable customers to replicate ERP materials to SAB Business Network Asset Collaboration models
  • Component suppliers and product manufacturers can leverage this feature to share technical information about their spare parts and products with SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration, starting from the corresponding existing materials in SAP ERP
  • Asset Operators can leverage this feature to share spare parts (i.e. components) associated to specific work orders and work order operations to external contractors, starting from the corresponding work orders and work order operations in SAP ERP (i.e. SAP Plant Maintenance)

Description:

  • For work orders and work order operations, you can now see a new tab called Components. Here, you can view the list of attached components and their related information. You can also share this list of components with your external contractors.

For more information, see Viewing a Work Order and Viewing the Operations to be performed for a Work Order.

 

 

Asset Administration Shell File Upload for Models (i.e. Types)

Scope:

  • You can now upload single AASX files through the user interface, facilitating the creation of model entries in SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration based on Asset Administration Shells (AAS). This enhancement streamlines the import process by associating the AAS-standardized submodel ‚ÄúHandover Documentation‚Äù efficiently.

    For more information, see Import Data.

Key Benefits:

  • Automate model creation with documents to significantly reduce manual data entry and the risk of errors
  • Simplify entry into advanced data ecosystems with AAS-compliant interfaces that eliminate the need for complex custom integration with broader data ecosystems, such as Factory-X

Description:

  • Upload methods: upload .aasx files either through the user interface
  • Asynchronous processing: handle the upload and creation process for the model and documents asynchronously and use the process ID to allow the data steward to monitor the progress
  • Result visibility: empower the data steward to check the status (success or failure) through the process ID and view the resulting model and associated documents in the Model application once the file is processed
  • Conflict management: specify whether to ignore or update existing equipment and document associations during upload if they already exist in SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Attribute-based Search for Documents

Scope:

  • Provide the ability to search and filter documents based on document attribute values

Key Benefits:

  • Find and filter the right documents based on attribute values
  • Consume document standards and corresponding attributes in daily business processes

Description:

  • You can now search for documents using the search field.

  • As part of the document search, you can filter the documents . A new filter option based on the document template is also available .

  • Attribute based search is also enabled.

 

 

Asset Administration Shell File Upload for Equipment

Scope:

  • The new feature allows you to upload a single AASX files through the user interface, facilitating the creation of equipment entries in SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration based on Asset Administration Shells (AAS). This enhancement streamlines the import process by associating AAS - standardized Submodels Digital Nameplate and Handover Documentation data efficiently, making it more user-friendly.

    For more information, see Import Data.

Key Benefits:

  • Automate equipment creation with digital nameplate and documents to significantly reduce manual data entry and the risk of errors
  • Integrate with SAP Plant Maintenance for smooth synchronization of digital twin data with existing maintenance processes, which helps ensure that the latest equipment data, along with its associated documentation, is readily available for maintenance teams
  • Simplify entry into advanced data ecosystems with AAS-compliant interfaces that eliminate the need for complex custom integration with broader data ecosystems, such as Factory-X

Description:

  • Upload methods: upload .aasx files either through the user interface
  • Asynchronous processing: handle the upload and creation process for the equipment, digital nameplate, and documents asynchronously and use the process ID to allow the data steward to monitor the progress
  • Result visibility: empower the data steward to check the status (success or failure) through the process ID and view the resulting equipment, digital nameplate, and associated documents in the Equipment application once the file is processed
  • Conflict management: specify whether to ignore or update existing equipment and document associations during upload if they already exist in SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration

Other Innovations

  • Header PATCH API for equipment
    • This feature allows you to update values for header fields of the specified equipment using the PATCH API. For more information, see Equipment API.
  • Specify values for components in model structure
    • This feature allows you to assign and maintain quantity values for each component in the model structure. The model record creation now supports the assignment of precise quantity or quantity range with decimal values based on the base Unit of Measure (UoM) of the assigned component, if the base UoM is different than Each and Piece. For more information, see Creating a Model.
  • Templates for notifications
    • You can now add templates to notifications to maintain and share attributes related to the notification. For more information, see Creating a Notification.
    • The APIs are enhanced for the same. For more information, see Notifications API.
  • New APIs for work orders
    • GET API available to retrieve a list of templates associated with a work order.
    • PUT API available to modify attribute value in a work order.
    • For more information, see Work Orders - API.
  • Notification enhancements
    • As a service provider, you can view the shared status of the notification in the list page. For more information, see Sharing a Notification.
    • You can edit the priority of notifications as long as they are not shared or synchronized with the ERP system. For more information, see Creating a Notification.

Upcoming Innovations

Following exciting innovations are planned for the upcoming major release of SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration:

  • Header PATCH APIs for functional locations
  • Representing and sharing product families and configurations
  • Integration of ERP Materials to BNAC Models (brownfield/mapping)
  • Enablement of advanced search for technical objects on Azure
  • Public GET & POST APIs for Work Order-Operation - Collaboration Statuses
  • Collaborative statuses for notifications
  • Asset Administration Shell REST APIs
  • Etc.

Submit innovation requests

We encourage you to visit the SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration Customer Influence Portal to submit your innovation requests and review and vote innovation requests submitted by other customers.

entry.content:
Hello @Dylan2 ,

Great to hear the company name is working!

For the legal provisions, the best approach is to create a new master page in Adobe LiveCycle Designer (Legal_Provisions) and leave ‚ÄúPlace at Start‚Äù and ‚ÄúPlace at End‚Äù unchecked. Then, use a subform that‚Äôs only shown when needed.
Just ensure the subform allows page breaks and isn‚Äôt placed inside a static container that blocks it.

SAP Community ‚Äì Creating New Master Page

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: ‚ÄãA Step-by-Step Guide to Build a Custom Mobile Apps for Warehouse Management Using SAP Build Code
entry.content:
Chapter 1: Define the Purpose 

This guide helps Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition partners and customers to build custom mobile applications by integrating the Warehouse Task and Warehouse Order (A2X) API (from SAP Business Accelerator Hub) with SAP Build Code-Mobile Develop Kit (MDK). To demonstrate seamless warehouse task management, we have created a step-by-step guide blog for developing a demo mobile app. Through this blog, you will learn: 

  • How to initiate the development of your mobile app project in SAP Build Code. 
  • How to quickly build the frontend using drag-and-drop UI components. 
  • How to trigger GET requests to retrieve warehouse tasks using no-code methods and additional JS code. 
  • How to deploy and run the demo app on mobile devices. 

Prerequisites   
Before starting development, ensure you have configured: 

  1. An SAP BTP subaccount. 
  2. Access to SAP Build Code. 
  3. Create your server destination and fill in your server URL and authorization method. 
  • Go to Connectivity > Destination section in BTP Cockpit. 

  • Enter your server configuration and "Save" your Service Destination. 

 

 

 

 

Chapter 2: Create a New Mobile Project    

1. In SAP Build Code Lobby, click "Create" -> "Create" to start the creation process. 

 

 

 2. Select "Application" and click "Next". 

 3. Choose "Mobile" and click "Next". 

 4. Choose "Mobile Application" and click "Next". 

5. Enter the Project Name as desired, select a Dev Space, and then click "Review". 

 6. Click "Create". 

 7. Wait until the project is created and click the project name to enter the web development studio. 

 

 

Chapter 3: Configure the Storyboard 

There are three types of settings that must be configured in the storyboard: 

  • Runtime Resources: View the mobile services application and mobile destination used in the project. 
  • External Resources: View the external services used in the project (including the OData data structure if utilized). 
  • UI Applications: View the mobile applications. 

1. Click any "+" button in the Runtime Resources section to add a mobile services app to your project. (You may need to log in if your Cloud Foundry login session has expired.) 

2. You can choose from the existing services list, or click the‚ÄØ"+"‚ÄØbutton to create a new mobile services app configuration. 

 

 
To create a new service, name your app and the app ID as desired on the Basic Information page, then click "Next". 

 

3. On the Destination page, select SAP Destination Service as the Destination type. Then click "Create App". 

Ensure that Cloud Destination has been configured in the Prerequisites (which uses the Server URL via the WOWT API: Warehouse Order and Task (A2X) - Overview | Warehouse Order and Task (A2X) | SAP Business Accelerator Hub 
 

Select the Server in your checkbox and click "Add App to Project". 

 

 

 4. Design and implement a user interface application. Click "+" button in UI Application. 

 

 5. Choose a template type (choosing any templates has no impact on this demo but it can accelerate the development) and click "Next". 

In "Select Service Type", choose REST, then click "Finish". 

 

 

Chapter 4: Integration REST Request Without Writing Code 

Then we will create a simple showcase to demonstrate the WOWT API's usability in SAP Build Code. This demo includes a basic screen with some UI components to send a "Get Warehouse Task" request to the server. The returned warehouse tasks will be displayed accordingly. Please ensure all prerequisite steps are completed before this chapter.  

Here is the example RESTful service request URL in this guide: 
{{TestServerURL}}/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_warehouse_order_task_2/srvd_a2x/sap/warehouseorder/0001/warehousetask 

As outlined in the prerequisites, we have already set the destination server URL to: 
{{TestServerURL}}/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_warehouse_order_task_2/srvd_a2x/sap/warehouseorder/0001 

1. In the left explorer panel, find the "Pages" folder, open it, then double click "Main.page". 

 

 2. Search for "Object Table" in the components list under ‚ÄúControls‚Äù on the left. And drag it to the primary interface. 

 3. Select the object table you just dragged onto the interface; there is a "properties setting" on its right side. In the properties setting of the object table, you need: 

- Select the REST Service Target  

- Select the service in "Service"(set in the previous chapter) 

- Enter the service address '/warehousetask ' of the WOWT API in "Path". 

- Set the "OutputPath" property value to '/value'. 

- Check the "Request Properties"- "Method" is GET (Default) 

The final settings should be as shown in the figure below. 

Service is your destination URL set before in this case: 
Path: property value is your corresponding RESTful request URL. 
OutputPath:‚ÄØproperty value is set to '/value'. This means that you only want the return data in 'value'. 
Example returns data as follows; we only want data in the 'value' path. 

4. Scroll down the properties setting of the object table, you need:           

- Find the input box named "Title" and enter ' wt:{WarehouseTask} ' 

- Find the input box named "Description" and enter ' {Product} ' 

- Find the input box named "StatusText" and enter ' wh:{EWMWarehouse} ' 

- Find the input box named "Subhead" and enter ' wo: {WarehouseOrder} ' 

 
In this demo, we display WarehouseOrder, WarehouseTask, Product and EWMWarehouse in the Object Table. You can also select the specific data you want to display and write it in the corresponding position of the Object Table Properties using the format {EntityName}. 

 

 

 

 

Chapter 5: Implement Using JavaScript Code (Advanced) 

If the provided basic methods fail to meet advanced requirements, built-in code can also be used for further customization. In this chapter, JavaScript code is employed to send the same "Get Warehouse Task" request with the code bound to a button. When triggered by a user click, the retrieved data will be displayed directly via an alert. For simplicity, the code here only displays raw data, but you can implement more complex logic during actual development. 

 

1. Create a new Rule by right clicking the Rules folder and selecting "MDK: New Rules". 

 

 2. Choose the "Empty JS Rule" and click "Next". 

 3. Enter the name "getWT" for the new JS Rule and click "Finish". Then, copy the following JS code into the generated "getWT.action" file.  

Code: 

export default function sendRequest(clientAPI) { 

// Replace {your_service_name} with your actual server‚Äôs name 

  const path = '/{your_service_name}/WarehouseTask?$top=1';  

  const params = { 

    'method': 'GET' 

  }; 

    

  return clientAPI.sendRequest(path, params).then(result => { 

    alert(result.content.toString()); 

  }); 

}

 

You need to replace {your_service_name} with the service name you are using. Your service name is the filename of the ".server" configuration file in the "Services" folder. 

4. Add a button to Main.page. 

5. Click on the button you added. There is a "properties setting" and "event" on its right side, click "Event", then bind the "Handler" to the "getWT" rule. 

 

 

Chapter 6: Deploy the Demo to Mobile 

1. Open the‚ÄØApplication.app‚ÄØfile, click the‚ÄØ"Deploy"‚ÄØoption in the editor's header area, and then choose the deployment target as‚ÄØ‚ÄúMobile Services‚Äù. 

2. Select deploy target as‚ÄØ"Mobile Services". (Cloud Web apps may not be suitable for RESTful services) 

If you want to enable source for debugging the deployed bundle, then choose‚ÄØ"Yes". 

You should see‚ÄØ"Deployed to Mobile Services successfully!"‚ÄØand current revision time. Ignore the other error messages in "PROBLEMS ". 

 

 

Chapter 7: Run the Demo on Mobile 

Using "Mobile Svcs" (download in app store) scan this QRcode and logon to run the latest version of your mobile app. 

Choose "Deploy" to generate QR code. 

The On-boarding QR code is now displayed. 

You must log in to your BTP account, and set a separate password for the mobile app. 

 

 

Chapter 8: Demo Real-Device Display Screenshots (Running on iPhone) 

After successfully launching the application, you will be able to view the object table created in Chapter 5, with its content automatically populated by the EWM warehouse, warehouse task, warehouse order, and product data retrieved from the request. 

Click the "button", and you will see an alert pop up displaying the raw data returned from the request, as shown in the figure below. 

 

 

 

 

Conclusion   

Building custom mobile apps for Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition doesn‚Äôt have to be a complex coding marathon with SAP Build Code, you can streamline warehouse management workflows by seamlessly integrating the WOWT API, leveraging no-code tools for rapid prototyping, and enhancing functionality with JavaScript for advanced use cases. This guide can equip you to deliver robust mobile solutions‚Äîfrom initial setup to deployment‚Äîwith confidence. 

Ready to build your own app?   

Start with the step-by-step guide and explore the SAP Build Code platform. Share your feedback or questions below‚Äîwe‚Äôd love to hear how you‚Äôre innovating in warehouse management! üöÄ 

 

 

Referenced Data and Additional Training Lessons 

Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Warehouse Task and Warehouse Order (A2X) API 
Warehouse Task and Warehouse Order (A2X) API (from SAP Business Accelerator Hub) 

 

Official tutorial web for mobile development kit clients. 

SAP Tutorial Navigator | Tutorials for SAP Developers 

 

Explore the mobile development kit SDK and build a custom Android/iOS client, enable push notifications, and create extensions. 

Brand Your Customized App with Mobile Development Kit SDK | SAP Tutorials 

 

Customize the look and feel of your MDK app with extension controls using metadata approach or Native script plugins. 

Create Extension Controls in Mobile Development Kit (MDK) Apps | SAP Tutorials 

 

Increase your understanding of the mobile development kit, learn how to create, delete a record, how to display the data from the related entity, and how to upload client logs to mobile services. 

Enhance Your First MDK App with Additional Functionalities | SAP Tutorials 

 

Become proficient with the mobile development kit by learning how to handle an error archive, add styling, deep link, and leverage OData annotations. 

Level Up with the Mobile Development Kit | SAP Tutorials 

 

Use the SAP Mobile Services mobile development kit (MDK) to create your first multi-channel (mobile and web) application, connect to an OData backend, and use MDK controls to enhance it.‚ÄØ 

Create Your First MDK Application | SAP Tutorials 

 
 
Features scope in SAP Build Code. 

https://help.sap.com/doc/DRAFT/a3a8555189a0481fb69c68f60142fa10/SHIP/en-US/FSD_EN.pdf 

 

Help document for Metadata reference. 
SendRequest - Mobile Development Kit References

entry.title: Journey Through Data Migration in an SAP BRIM Implementation
entry.content:
I am glad to share my experience in migrating data in an SAP BRIM project, based on SAP‚Äôs Hi-Tech Industry Template designed for implementing BRIM solution. While there is already a wealth of information available online covering BRIM overviews and its components from functional standpoint, my intent is to focus specifically on the data migration aspects of BRIM implementations. I trust this blog will offer meaningful insights for anyone engaged in data migration activities in a BRIM implementation.

 

Act Early, Act Right: Reduce Delays

Migration Objects List
Identifying key data objects for migration at an early stage is critical to the success of any data migration effort. Early identification allows for better planning, timely preparation, and smooth execution of migration activities, ensuring alignment with overall project timelines and objectives.

In most cases, a complete list of migration objects is determined during the Fit-to-Standard workshops. Below is a list of typical BRIM data objects; however, please note that the final object-list may vary depending on factors such as the specific BRIM components being implemented and the functionalities activated in the system etc.

BRIM Data ObjectsBRIM ModuleMigration Tool: Object
BP Customer MasterSAP SOMMigration Cockpit: Customer
Contract AccountBRIM CIEMIGALL: ACCOUNT 
Subscription ProductsBRIM SOM

Migration Cockpit:
Product
Product - extend existing record by new org levels
Object classification - General template

EMIGALL: PRODUCT1

Rate Cards (BRIM) or Pricing data (SD)BRIM CCStd. Fiori app: Maintain Prices ‚Äì Sales

Solution Quotation / Subscription OrderBRIM SOMCustom ABAP program
Subscription ContractBRIM SOMCustom ABAP program
Consumption Items (CIT) UploadBRIM CIStd. Fiori app: Upload Consumption Items
Std. T-code: FKKBIXCIT_UPLOAD
Billable Items (BIT) UploadBRIM CIStd. Fiori app: Upload Billable Items
Std. T-code: FKKBIXBIT_UPLOAD
Open Items FI-CABRIM FI-CAEMIGALL: DOCUMENT
Dunning ItemsBRIM FI-CAEMIGALL: DUNNING

 

Key Activities
As with any SAP implementation, the following are some of the critical activities and deliverables from a data migration perspective.

Migration roadmap & Data Migration Strategy
Data Migration Strategy document is a formal deliverable that outlines the plan about how data will be migrated from legacy systems into SAP environment. It serves as a blueprint for ensuring that the right data is migrated accurately, securely, and efficiently ‚Äì with minimal or no impact on the overall project timeline. In short, you document the list of data objects in scope, systems involved (source and target), migration tools to be used, roles and responsibilities (RACI), planned load cycles/ phases with timelines, acceptance criteria/ quality gate checks etc.

It is always recommended to initiate this work as early as possible in the project and continue to amend ‚Äì with regular updates to reflect improvements in the plan, process, or overall migration approach. Though this would be a living document (as there would be scope to amend detailed information), the core process needs to be agreed and formally signed by the customer by end of EXPLORE phase.

Mapping Workshops & Mapping Documents
Having a detailed mapping document for each data object being migrated is essential ‚Äì especially for high-volume and complex objects such as Subscription Products, Customer Master and Solution Quotation/ Subscription Orders. This document should capture the source table structure, target structure (that matches with the upload template), and all relevant details including conversion logic, deduplication rules, default values, cross-reference lookups and key observations.

It is equally important to review and validate the mapping document with your ETL experts to ensure it contains the appropriate level of detail. This is crucial, as the ETL developers will ultimately be responsible for building the transformations required for data uploads. Please note that mapping document should be maintained and regularly updated during the mapping workshops. Having the right set of participants in these sessions is crucial. Ideally, the workshops should include data owners, key business users, and customer IT team members who understand the AS-IS state of the data object, along with SAP functional experts who would be defining the TO-BE state. However, in practice, it's often challenging to have all these stakeholders available at the same time for extended discussions. In addition, a fully detailed functional design may not be ready at the time of the workshops. Therefore, it's more effective to structure your mapping workshops as a series of recurring or iterative sessions, rather than a single lengthy 3-hour meeting for example. This approach allows you to capture requirements progressively, in alignment with the evolving functional design.

A finalized and comprehensive mapping document for all key data objects should be prepared as early as possible during the REALIZE phase, to enable timely initiation of build and test activities and avoid delays in starting the initial mock load cycle.

Build & Testing of Custom Upload Programs
For custom upload programs, it is critical to ensure development and unit-testing are completed before starting a full mock load cycle. Prerequisite for this is a comprehensive documentation, with particular emphasis on a detailed unit test script that outlines all necessary scenarios - especially those covering the services being implemented for billing automation.


Right Tools for Migration
To support the end-to-end data migration process, there are several ETL tools available in the market that can be used for data extraction and transformation. In our BRIM implementation, we used Informatica, as it was already in use by the customer for other IT initiatives. Since this component was fully owned and managed by the customer, I won‚Äôt go into detail about the extraction and transformation tooling.

For the data upload, SAP tools like Migration Cockpit and EMIGALL (ISMW) are commonly used in BRIM projects. Alternatively, a custom solution can be developed if standard objects provided by these tools do not meet specific requirements. In practice, most projects end up using a combination of these tools to meet overall migration needs.

Migration Cockpit
Migration Cockpit (Fiori app name Migrate Your Data) is SAP‚Äôs standard tool for data migration ‚Äì from legacy systems to S/4HANA. Here are some key features of Migration Cockpit are:

  • Pre-configured, guided and user-friendly. You can download migration template, fill data, and migrate data.
  • Provides standard content (pre-delivered migration objects). However no standard content currently available for migration of key BRIM objects like solution quotes, subscription orders or subscription contracts.

EMIGALL (ISMW)
EMIGALL tool, also referred to as ISMW (Industry Specific Migration Workbench), is a very effective tool in migrating legacy data to SAP IS-Utilities and SAP BRIM environments. Some of the key features of EMIGALL are:

  • BRIM involves integration of multiple modules like Subscription Order Management, Convergent Charging and Convergent Invoicing. EMIGALL, as a tool, is very effective in migration of interconnected data like BP-customers, contract accounts, provider contracts and subscription products etc.
  • Provides standard content (pre-delivered migration objects) for BRIM related data objects.
  • Performs checks and validation before actual upload step.

Custom solution for data-upload:
Several APIs are available as OData services that could be called via ABAP program to post/ upload data. These are also available to be called externally to post data into target BRIM system.

 

Migration Approach for Key Data Objects
Here, we outline the possible approaches available and explain the option we selected to proceed with.

Business Partner ‚Äì Customer Master
Standard migration objects are available for migrating customer master using both tools ‚Äì Migration Cockpit and EMIGALL. We had used below listed migration templates from Migration Cockpit tool.

  • Customer
  • Customer - extend existing record by Credit Management data

Contract Account
Standard migration object ACCOUNT is available to migrate Contract Accounts via EMIGALL tool. Alternatively, you can also call OData service API_CONTRACTACCOUNT to create Contract Accounts. You can refer the link Overview | Contract Account | SAP Business Accelerator Hub, for more details on this API.

Subscription Products
BRIM products are created with product type SUBS (subscription). These are often service based products and fundamentally different from traditional products in how it's designed, managed, billed, and consumed. In principle these refer to services that are recurring in nature (like monthly, quarterly or yearly) or even one-time (like a physical product or a one-time service). In most SAP BRIM implementations, we‚Äôve seen a need to normalize products during migration. This typically involves consolidating multiple legacy products into a single product in the target system, represented with multiple variants. To support this, all BRIM products are created as Advanced Variant Configuration (AVC) relevant, with classification data based on variant class type 300.

So, as part of subscription product setup.

  • You first create required characteristics, then assign those to relevant classes, and further assign these class to subscription products. For this, we had used Migration Cockpit to migrate characteristics, classes and subscription products. Alternatively, EMIGALL could be used too.
  • You also assign a configuration profile to subscription product.
  • Furthermore, for downstream processing in SAP BRIM, it is mandatory to assign Cross Catalog Mapping (CCM) data to the subscription product. This assignment can be performed manually using the Fiori app Manage Subscription Product-Specific Data. To automate this process for migration, we developed a custom solution that assigns CCM data to subscription products. We leveraged SAP standard class/method CL_CRMS4_SOM_PROD_SPEC_API / CREATE_PRODUCT_SPECIFIC. Alternatively, standard function module CRMS4_SOM_SPEC_PROD_UPDATE could be used too.

Pricing data / Rate Card Data
In our project, rate cards were implemented using condition records. A standard Fiori app Maintain Prices ‚Äì Sales is available to maintain rate card information. This app has import / export capability and allows us to create multiple condition records simultaneously.

Master Agreement
For Master Agreement migration, you can use OData service API_SRVCTRANSMASTERAGRMT. For detailed information, refer the link Overview | Master Agreement | SAP Business Accelerator Hub. In our case, we used the standard function module CRM_ORDER_MAINTAIN to build custom ABAP program. Alternatively, API CRMS4_SOM_MASTER_AGREEMENT_MIG can be used to build a migration object using EMIGALL tool (Migration Class as BAPI). Technically, at a minimum, we need to map header, partner, item and variant configuration data to IT_GEN_DATA, IT_ALT_PARTNER, IT_ITEMS and IT_ITEM_CONFIG tables respectively, when calling this function module.

For our customer, the Master Agreement document served as the initial (or base) document in the SAP BRIM process flow. Additionally, there was a need to map additional information like terms and agreements captured as long texts in their source system, these were mapped to table IT_ITEM_CUSTOM_TXT.

Solution Quotation
We built a custom ABAP program by calling function module CRM_ORDER_MAINTAIN to migrate Solution Quotations. The same function module could be used to create Subscription Orders also; however, the Process Type and specific segments that you map would differ. Below listed are some of the key export and table parameters that we mapped;

  • IT_ORGMAN, communication structure with org data for the agreement
  • CT_ORDERADM_H, header information
  • CT_ORDERADM_I, line-item information
  • CT_INPUT_FIELDS, technical information of each attribute being mapping during API call
  • IT_CONFIG, with variant configuration data for each item

Within the program flow, post calling CRM_ORDER_MAINTAIN, we had to call below listed function modules to complete the creation process.

  • CRM_MESSAGES_DISPLAY and CRM_MESSAGES_GET_MSG_INFO to capture and manage error messages.
  • CRM_ORDER_SAVE, to save the CRM document being created.
  • CRM_ORDER_INITIALIZE, called after the save call to ensure release of any locks held during CRM document creation.
  • Finally followed by a call to BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT, to commits the data to CRM database.

Alternatively, you can use OData Service API_BUS_SOLUTION_QUOTATION_SRV to create Solution Quotations. This service is part of the "Solution Quotation (A2X)" functionality within SAP's API landscape. For detailed information, refer the link Overview | Solution Quotation (A2X) | SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Subscription Contract
In this project, the creation of Subscription Contracts was automatically triggered by status changes in Solution Quotation items - initially the status is set to ‚ÄúAccept,‚Äù followed by a status change to ‚ÄúRelease‚Äù. We had developed a custom ABAP program to call function module CRM_STATUS_MAINTAIN_OW to change the status. This function call is followed by call to CRM_ORDER_SAVE_OW and CRM_ORDER_INITIALIZE to complete Subs. Contract creation process.

In our case, the generation of Subscription Contracts in SOM would further trigger auto creation of Provider Contracts in SAP CC for further processing.

Consumption Items (CIT) Upload
A Consumption Item (CIT) represents usage or consumption data and consists of multiple attributes describing that usage. CIT Upload refers to the process of importing this usage data ‚Äì typically coming from external systems ‚Äì using a predefined upload structure. This data is later billed through the BRIM solution.
CITs can be uploaded using the transaction code FKKBIXCIT_UPLOAD or the Fiori app Upload Consumption Items.
Once uploaded, a CIT enters a rateable status. Upon rating, it generates a Billable Item (BIT), which includes the final calculated amount for billing and invoicing.

Billable Items (BIT) Upload
As mentioned in earlier step, Billable Items (BIT) are rated items that can be processed for final billing. If there's a need to upload BITs, you can use the transaction code FKKBIXBIT_UPLOAD or the Fiori app Upload Billable Items.

FI-CA Open Items & Dunning Items
A standard migration object DOCUMENT via EMIGALL / ISMW tool could be used to migrate FI-CA open items. In case of dunning items, you could use migration object DUNNING via EMIGALL / ISMW tool.
Alternatively, you can build a custom program to call function module BAPI_CTRACDOCUMENT_CREATE to migrate FI-CA open items, followed by BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT call.

 

Critical Points
Compared to other SAP implementations, SAP BRIM presents a unique challenge due to the tight integration and high interdependence among its core components‚Äîsuch as Subscription Order Management (SOM), Convergent Charging (CC), Convergent Invoicing (CI), Contract Accounts Receivable and Payable (FI-CA), and other mediation platforms.
Testing data migration objects in isolation can result in missed integration issues, which are likely to surface during System Integration Testing cycles. Therefore, it‚Äôs essential to approach testing with an end-to-end perspective to ensure smooth cross-component functionality. I strongly recommend testing key activities like CIT uploads (using realistic consumption data, as we faced issues validating it) and billing cycle within at least one comprehensive mock load cycle prior to production migration.

entry.title: Searching Substrings in the Element Information Popup in ADT for Eclipse
entry.content:
Do you know the search capabilities for substrings in the element information popup? If no, grab a cup of coffee and enjoy reading my blog.

Your task: A colleague asks you to fix a UI behavior for a given element of a CDS entity that is provided by an extension. You don‚Äôt know in which data definition the element is located in.

Your goal: You want to find out from which CDS entity extension an element is provided. Usually, a CDS entity contains a huge number of elements provided by multiple data definitions.

 

Procedure

Let's go into details and follow my instruction:

  1. Open the relevant development object in ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse (ADT).
  2. Navigate to the occurrence of the element in question in the source code and hit F2.
    The element information popup will then be opened.
  3. Skim through the content.
  4. Do you want to see all relating elements and their location in a CDS entity extension on a structured and clear way? Perfect. Switch to the structured display. Just choose the  Details view with include/append structure button on the toolbar on the bottom.

    ADT then opens the structured element information:

    The elements are sorted like they are defined in the source code. In addition, this tabular structured display shows the CDS entity extension in which the elements are located in. For example, the elements seats_max and seats_occuped are located in DDLS DEMO_TEST_CDS_EXTEND_VIEW.
  5. You are now just a second away from your goal: Search for the substring. To open the search, hit the  Search button from the toolbar on the bottom.

    Note: The search feature in the structured display is supported as of ADT client version 3.52.
  6. Enter your search pattern in the Find input field and confirm with Enter.

Result

Here we go! ADT highlights all findings for you! The first finding is highlighted with a blue box, all the remaining ones with a grey box.

To navigate to an element information popup of a target or a component type, hover and click the underlined name. 

Related Information

You want to find more ADT-specific tips & tricks? Have fun with this help content:

  • ABAP core development
  • ABAP CDS development

entry.title: Re: SAC: Issue with data load, error 1016
entry.content: We faced the same issue and in our case it turned out that Document Store related to the datasource query was set to 'inactive' in BW. Probably because of the query changes applied. I got a detailed error description pointing to the Document Store name and status, when I was trying to adjust query variables in the SAC Import job. Otherwise I got only this meaning nothing "Issue with data load, error 1016". Once the Doc.Store was activated in BW, all SAC import jobs were running correctly again. So there was no need to recreate all the jobs.

entry.title: Extended situation handling issues on SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS03 ?
entry.content:
Hello Dear Expert,

I‚Äôm currently facing some issues while configuring Situation Handling for parked accounting documents ‚Äî specifically, when a document is parked using transaction MIR7, I want a notification to be triggered.

I created a custom CDS view that retrieves only parked accounting documents, and here are the different approaches I‚Äôve tested:

1. Object-Based Event ‚Äì BOR

  • Event Category: BOR Object Type      Event Object: FIPP           Event Type: COMPLETED

  • Result: No instance detected

2. Object-Based Event ‚Äì ABAP Class

  • Event Category: ABAP Class   Event Object: CL_FINS_JOURNALENTRY_SOT_EVENT  Event Type: CREATED

  • Result: No instance detected

3. Job-Based Trigger

  • Result: Works correctly.
    I receive the notification and the details appear in the "My Situations ‚Äì Extended" app.

However, I‚Äôm still facing two issues:

  • The situation doesn‚Äôt appear in the "My Situations" section on the Home screen.

  • The job can only be scheduled every 3 hours, not more frequently.

My questions:

  1. In the case of Event-based triggers, which event should I choose? Why does it say "No instance detected"?

  2. Why is the notification shown only in the Inbox icon, but not in the "My Situations" section on the Home screen?

  3. With Job-based triggers, how can I schedule the job to run every 5 minutes instead of every 3 hours?

Thanks in advance.

Mben!
